You are DocIntel, a medical document analysis AI. Extract structured information from clinical documents. Return valid JSON matching the provided schema. Include diagnoses with ICD-10 codes, medications, procedures, lab results, and follow-up recommendations.

Analyze this medical document and extract structured information:

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Department: Endocrinology
Attending: Dr. Nguyen
Admission Date: 2025-07-29
Discharge Date: 2025-08-02

Patient is a 78-year-old female admitted for evaluation and management of Suspected Thyroid Nodule. She presented with symptoms consistent with suspected thyroid nodule and was admitted for further workup.

DIAGNOSES:
Suspected Thyroid Nodule, Deep Vein Thrombosis, Cellulitis of lower limb

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Chest X-ray: Small pericardial effusion, hemodynamically stable
  - Cardiac catheterization: Significant findings requiring further evaluation
  - Doppler ultrasound of lower extremities: No evidence of obstruction or mass

LABORATORY RESULTS:
  - Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL (normal)
  - HbA1c: 4.7 % (normal)
  - Platelet Count: 266 x10^3/uL (normal)
  - Potassium: 4.7 mEq/L (normal)
  - BUN: 17.0 mg/dL (normal)

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
  - Lisinopril 10mg once daily (oral)
  - Acetaminophen 650mg every 6 hours as needed (oral)
  - Metoprolol Succinate 25mg once daily (oral)
  - Omeprazole 20mg once daily before breakfast (oral)
  - Aspirin 81mg once daily (oral)

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
  - Cardiac rehabilitation evaluation with Endocrinology in 1 month

The patient was discharged in stable condition after a 4-day stay. She was counseled on medication compliance and return precautions.

Return JSON with: document_type, patient_info, diagnoses (with ICD-10 codes), medications, procedures, lab_results, follow_up, and summary.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Department: Orthopedics
Attending: Dr. Wang
Admission Date: 2025-10-11
Discharge Date: 2025-10-12

Patient is a 72-year-old female admitted for evaluation and management of Acute Upper Respiratory Infection. She presented with symptoms consistent with acute upper respiratory infection and was admitted for further workup.

DIAGNOSES:
Acute Upper Respiratory Infection

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Chest X-ray: Mild abnormality noted, recommend follow-up
  - CT scan of chest with contrast: Small pericardial effusion, hemodynamically stable
  - Upper GI endoscopy: No intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect

LABORATORY RESULTS:
  - Bicarbonate: 23.9 mEq/L (normal)
  - HbA1c: 5.5 % (normal)
  - Total Bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL (normal)
  - Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L (normal)

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
  - Ibuprofen 400mg every 6 hours as needed (oral)
  - Metoprolol Succinate 50mg once daily (oral)
  - Levothyroxine 75mcg once daily on empty stomach (oral)
  - Gabapentin 300mg three times daily (oral)
  - Lisinopril 20mg once daily (oral)

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
  - Follow-up with primary care physician with Endocrinology in 3 months
  - Cardiac rehabilitation evaluation with Neurology in 6 weeks

The patient was discharged in stable condition after a 1-day stay. She was counseled on medication compliance and return precautions.

Patient: 57-year-old female

SUBJECTIVE:
Patient reports feeling better overall. She is currently taking 5 medication(s).

OBJECTIVE:

Focused exam consistent with iron deficiency anemia.

RECENT LABS: Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL, Platelet Count 228 x10^3/uL, ESR 18.8 mm/hr, TSH 3.6 mIU/L, Bicarbonate 27.3 mEq/L

Iron Deficiency Anemia - stable.

PLAN:

Order repeat labs.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Department: Infectious Disease
Attending: Dr. Brown
Admission Date: 2023-09-08
Discharge Date: 2023-09-20

Patient is a 60-year-old female admitted for evaluation and management of Stroke, cerebral infarction. She presented with symptoms consistent with stroke, cerebral infarction and was admitted for further workup.

DIAGNOSES:
Stroke, cerebral infarction, Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Acute Myocardial Infarction

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Knee arthroscopy: Significant findings requiring further evaluation

LABORATORY RESULTS:
  - ESR: 4.2 mm/hr (normal)
  - Chloride: 78.7 mEq/L (low)
  - BNP: 44 pg/mL (normal)
  - Troponin I: 0.1 ng/mL (high)
  - Glucose: 68.6 mg/dL (low)
  - AST: 53.2 U/L (high)
  - HbA1c: 5.1 % (normal)
  - Hemoglobin: 18.3 g/dL (high)

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
  - Metoprolol Succinate 25mg once daily (oral)
  - Azithromycin 250mg once daily (oral)
  - Amlodipine 5mg once daily (oral)
  - Atorvastatin 40mg once daily at bedtime (oral)
  - Insulin Glargine 20 units once daily at bedtime (subcutaneous)
  - Morphine 2mg every 4 hours as needed (IV)
  - Warfarin 5mg once daily (oral)

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
  - Follow-up imaging study with Primary Care in 1 week

The patient was discharged in stable condition after a 12-day stay. She was counseled on medication compliance and return precautions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Department: Internal Medicine
Attending: Dr. Wilson
Admission Date: 2025-10-01
Discharge Date: 2025-10-07

Patient is a 73-year-old female admitted for evaluation and management of Hypothyroidism. She presented with symptoms consistent with hypothyroidism and was admitted for further workup.

DIAGNOSES:
Hypothyroidism, Diabetic Nephropathy, Community-Acquired Pneumonia, Essential Hypertension

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Cholecystectomy: Results within normal limits

LABORATORY RESULTS:
  - Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L (normal)
  - Total Bilirubin: 1.1 mg/dL (normal)
  - Chloride: 105.6 mEq/L (normal)
  - White Blood Cell Count: 9.9 x10^3/uL (normal)
  - Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL (normal)
  - AST: 38.6 U/L (normal)

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
  - Ciprofloxacin 500mg twice daily (oral)
  - Morphine 2mg every 4 hours as needed (IV)
  - Metformin 500mg twice daily (oral)
  - Lisinopril 10mg once daily (oral)
  - Vancomycin 1g every 12 hours (IV)

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
  - Referral to specialist with Primary Care in 1 month

The patient was discharged in stable condition after a 6-day stay. She was counseled on medication compliance and return precautions.

DIAGNOSES:
Migraine without aura, Acute Myocardial Infarction

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Upper GI endoscopy: Small pericardial effusion, hemodynamically stable

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Department: Rheumatology
Attending: Dr. Williams
Admission Date: 2024-02-21
Discharge Date: 2024-02-28

Patient is a 38-year-old female admitted for evaluation and management of Pulmonary Embolism. She presented with symptoms consistent with pulmonary embolism and was admitted for further workup.

DIAGNOSES:
Pulmonary Embolism, Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Acute Kidney Injury, Cellulitis of lower limb

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted and started on appropriate therapy. She underwent the following evaluations:
  - Central line placement: Focal consolidation in right lower lobe

LABORATORY RESULTS:
  - ESR: 21.5 mm/hr (high)
  - Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL (low)
  - TSH: 0.3 mIU/L (low)
  - Chloride: 100.6 mEq/L (normal)
  - Procalcitonin: 0.1 ng/mL (normal)
  - Sodium: 124.6 mEq/L (low)
  - Glucose: 71.7 mg/dL (normal)
  - D-Dimer: 0 ng/mL (low)

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
  - Metoprolol Succinate 50mg once daily (oral)
  - Lisinopril 20mg once daily (oral)
  - Metoprolol Succinate 25mg once daily (oral)
  - Insulin Glargine 20 units once daily at bedtime (subcutaneous)
  - Atorvastatin 20mg once daily at bedtime (oral)
  - Albuterol 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed (inhaled)
  - Metformin 500mg twice daily (oral)

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
  - Cardiac rehabilitation evaluation with Endocrinology in 3 weeks

The patient was discharged in stable condition after a 7-day stay. She was counseled on medication compliance and return precautions.
